title: 115_s508
content:
The "Western Oregon Tribal Fairness Act" includes provisions for land conveyance for the Cow Creek Umpqua tribe and the Oregon Coastal tribe, as well as amendments to the Coquille Restoration Act. TITLE I--COW CREEK UMPQUA LAND CONVEYANCE

SEC. 101. DEFINITIONS.

    Council Creek land: approximately 17,519 acres of land depicted on the map titled "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance" dated May 24, 2016.
    Tribe: Cow Creek Band of Umpqua Tribe of Indians.
    Secretary: Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 102. LAND TO BE HELD IN TRUST. SEC. 102. LAND TO BE HELD IN TRUST.

All right, title, and interest of the United States in the Council Creek land shall be held in trust by the United States for the benefit of the Tribe and part of the Tribe's reservation. A survey to establish boundaries must be completed within 2 years. SEC. 103. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION.

The Secretary will file a map and legal description of the Council Creek land with the Senate and House Committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct any errors. The information will be available for public inspection. Unless expressly provided, this title does not affect any existing rights or claims of the Tribe to land. Federal laws on exporting unprocessed logs from Federal land apply to logs from Council Creek. Land taken into trust cannot be used for gaming activities. Forest management on Council Creek land must comply with Federal laws. The Secretary must secure administrative access to Council Creek land with the Tribe within 180 days. Reciprocal right-of-way agreements for access to the land must be provided to the Tribe. The Tribe must continue access once the land is taken into trust. The Tribe will have perpetual access to Council Creek land as per agreements, and once the land is in trust, it will not be subject to federal land use planning requirements. SEC. 105. LAND RECLASSIFICATION. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Tribe within 180 days. Within 2 years, public domain land in Oregon must be identified, similar in acreage and condition to the grant land. Maps must be submitted to Congress and published within 3 years. After identifying Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Tribe, the Secretary shall reclassify the land as Oregon and California Railroad grant land after public comment. The Act of August 28, 1937, shall apply to the reclassified land. TITLE II--OREGON COASTAL LAND CONVEYANCE

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.

    Definitions:
            (1) Confederated Tribes: Confederated Tribes of Coos, Lower Umpqua, and Siuslaw Indians.
            (2) Oregon Coastal land: Approximately 14,742 acres of land depicted on the map dated July 11, 2016.
            (3) Secretary: Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 202. LAND TO BE HELD IN TRUST. SEC. 202. LAND TO BE HELD IN TRUST. The United States will hold all right, title, and interest in Oregon Coastal land in trust for the Confederated Tribes, to be part of their reservation. A survey to establish boundaries must be completed within 2 years. SEC. 203. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of Oregon Coastal land with specified committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The information will be available for public inspection. SEC. 204. ADMINISTRATION. (a) Unless provided otherwise in this title, existing rights of the Confederated Tribes to land are preserved. 
(b) Prohibitions include restrictions on exporting unprocessed logs from Federal land and prohibiting gaming activities on land taken into trust under section 202. 
(c) Forest management on Oregon Coastal land must comply with Federal laws. 
(d) Agreements will be made regarding the management of the land. The Secretary will seek to enter into an agreement with the Confederated Tribes securing administrative access to Oregon Coastal land for various activities including forest management, timber haul, road maintenance, fire protection, surveys, and law enforcement. The Secretary aims to secure access to Oregon Coastal land for activities such as forest management, timber haul, road maintenance, fire protection, surveys, and law enforcement. This includes managing the land acquired under title 54, facilitating public vehicular transit to the Hult Log Storage Reservoir, and ensuring terms of any agreement for transit are upheld even if maintenance of the recreation site is discontinued. The Secretary will provide reciprocal right-of-way agreements to the Confederated Tribes for Oregon Coastal land, ensuring continued access in perpetuity. Once Oregon Coastal land is taken into trust under section 202, it is exempt from federal land use planning requirements. SEC. 205. LAND RECLASSIFICATION. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad grant land held in trust for the Confederated Tribes within 180 days. Within 2 years, public domain land in Oregon must be identified, equal in acreage and condition to the grant land, excluding Klamath County. Maps must be provided within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will reclassify the identified land as Oregon and California Railroad grant land after public comment, and the Act of August 28, 1937 will apply to the reclassified land. AMENDMENTS TO COQUILLE RESTORATION ACT: Section 301 involves amendments to the Coquille Restoration Act. Amendment to the Coquille Restoration Act involves the management of the Coquille Forest in accordance with laws for Indian trust land, including restrictions on exporting unprocessed logs. The Coquille Restoration Act amendment involves managing the Coquille Forest under Indian trust land laws, including restrictions on exporting unprocessed logs. Federal land sales of timber must follow competitive bidding practices, with the highest responsible bidder awarded the sale.
